TEXT.id: PaiwanCh2_016_THE CHILD WHO WENT UP TO HEAVEN
TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: kakeḍian a łevavaw itjua kalevelevan (Qatsiłay village, p.185)

S.FORM: uzai ka sitsuayan a mareałak i kavavuan a karakudakuda.
ozai ka sicoayan a marealjak i kavavoan a karakodakoda.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there was a family working in the fields.

S.FORM: a ałak a tjavulung a vavayan nasemvał tua kaka tjałałak a uqałay.
a aljak a tjavolong a vavayan nasemvalj toa kaka tjaljaljak a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: The older child, a girl, was carrying her younger brother on her back;

S.FORM: qau karakudakuda a kina.
qao karakodakoda a kina.
S.TRANSL: and the mother was working.

S.FORM: manu qemaung a sinvał a kaka.
mano qemaong a sinvalj a kaka.
S.TRANSL: The brother being carried started crying.

S.FORM: qau katsuin nua nasemvał a kaka tjavulung a vavayan a sema tjua kina, sa kiłavarani a kina tua patutu tazua kaka a tjałałak.
qao kacoin noa nasemvalj a kaka tjavolong a vavayan a sema tjoa kina, sa kiljavarani a kina toa patoto tazoa kaka a tjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: So his older sister who was carrying him took him to their mother, and asked her mother to suckle the younger brother.

S.FORM: manu "malatjak tu karakuda," ayain nua kina.
mano "malatjak to karakoda," ayain noa kina.
S.TRANSL: “I must get on with the work,” her mother said to her,

S.FORM: qau ini patutu-i.
qao ini patoto-i.
S.TRANSL: and she wouldn’t suckle him.

S.FORM: łakua "matsuła aravats; patutu-i anan," ayain a mumał a kiłavaran a kina.
ljakoa "macolja aravac; patoto-i anan," ayain a momalj a kiljavaran a kina.
S.TRANSL: But she said again to her mother: “He’s very hungry; stop and suckle him,” she said.

S.FORM: łakua ini patsunguł.
ljakoa ini pacongolj.
S.TRANSL: But she wouldn’t agree (OR feed him).

S.FORM: "kemudanga ken?" aya azua keḍikeḍian a semvał, tu sika mapiq anga timadju, maya sika qemauqaung azua keḍikeḍi a sinvał tua tsułan.
"kemodanga ken?" aya azoa kedrikedrian a semvalj, to sika mapiq anga timadjo, maya sika qemaoqaong azoa kedrikedri a sinvalj toa coljan.
S.TRANSL: “What am I to do?” said the child who was carrying him, as she was tired; not to mention that the child she was carrying was crying with hunger.

S.FORM: ini anga purukuz tu kemuda.
ini anga porokoz to kemoda.
S.TRANSL: She couldn’t decide what to do.

S.FORM: vaik anga łevavaw tua mui a qatsiłay.
vaik anga ljevavaw toa moi a qaciljay.
S.TRANSL: She went and climbed on a quartz rock.

S.FORM: qau sa senay azua keḍikeḍi a tjavulung.
qao sa senay azoa kedrikedri a tjavolong.
S.TRANSL: The older child sang,

S.FORM: qau manu lemadenga a tsemas tua senay nazua keḍikeḍi.
qao mano lemadenga a cemas toa senay nazoa kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: and (a) god heard the child’s song.

S.FORM: mangtjez a tsemas a kiqenetj.
mangtjez a cemas a kiqenetj.
S.TRANSL: The god came to look,

S.FORM: mintu penaula a tsemas.
minto penaola a cemas.
S.TRANSL: and had pity on them.

S.FORM: sualapen a kaka tjałałak a sinvał; sa katsu-i a sema kalevelevan azua kaka a tjavulung.
soalapen a kaka tjaljaljak a sinvalj; sa kaco-i a sema kalevelevan azoa kaka a tjavolong.
S.TRANSL: The younger brother was taken off her back, and the older sister was taken to heaven.

S.FORM: qau azua kaka a tjałałak sisekam nua tsemas sa paqerengi.
qao azoa kaka a tjaljaljak sisekam noa cemas sa paqerengi.
S.TRANSL: And the god made a bed for the younger brother and laid him down to sleep.

S.FORM: qau seleman anga avan anga qaung a ladengadengan nua kina.
qao seleman anga avan anga qaong a ladengadengan noa kina.
S.TRANSL: After dark the mother heard a cry.

S.FORM: qau penaula.
qao penaola.
S.TRANSL: She felt sorry.

S.FORM: "ku vaikaw anan a kiqenetj tu kemudakuda," aya a kina.
"ko vaikaw anan a kiqenetj to kemodakoda," aya a kina.
S.TRANSL: “I’ll go and see what’s happening,” said the mother,

S.FORM: vaiken sa kiqenetji.
vaiken sa kiqenetji.
S.TRANSL: and went to have a look.

S.FORM: mintu avan anga tjałałak a ałak a naqemereng a qemauqaung.
minto avan anga tjaljaljak a aljak a naqemereng a qemaoqaong.
S.TRANSL: There was the younger child lying down and crying.

S.FORM: qau mapuvarung azua kina.
qao mapovarong azoa kina.
S.TRANSL: The mother was anxious,

S.FORM: karimen azua ałak a tjavulung.
karimen azoa aljak a tjavolong.
S.TRANSL: and searched for the older child.

S.FORM: mareka qauqavan; łakua nekangata.
mareka qaoqavan; ljakoa nekangata.
S.TRANSL: She kept shouting, but there was no sign of her.

S.FORM: qau miseleman anga, nekangata.
qao miseleman anga, nekangata.
S.TRANSL: It got dark, but there was no sign of the child.

S.FORM: vaik anga a tjumaq azua kina, sa tjumałi a kama.
vaik anga a tjomaq azoa kina, sa tjomalji a kama.
S.TRANSL: The mother went home and told the father.

S.FORM: qau mapuvarung a kama katua kina.
qao mapovarong a kama katoa kina.
S.TRANSL: Father and mother were both anxious,

S.FORM: tsemangitsangitj anga i tjumaq sakamaya.
cemangicangitj anga i tjomaq sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: and just wailed at home.

S.FORM: mintu sika pitju a qadaw tu kinaulavan nazua keḍikeḍi, mangtjez azua keḍikeḍi a tjumaq.
minto sika pitjo a qadaw to kinaolavan nazoa kedrikedri, mangtjez azoa kedrikedri a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: Then on the seventh day from the loss of the child, the child came home.

S.FORM: łakua qatsanga aravats, bulay anga uta.
ljakoa qacanga aravac, bolay anga ota.
S.TRANSL: But she was very tall and beautiful too.

S.FORM: qau ini kełang a marekakama tu nima a ałak.
qao ini keljang a marekakama to nima a aljak.
S.TRANSL: Her parents didn’t know whose child she was,

S.FORM: qau kivadaqan tu kasinu a tsautsau, tu tima a ngadan nimadju.
qao kivadaqan to kasino a caocao, to tima a ngadan nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: and asked her where she came from and what her name was.

S.FORM: qau tjemumał azua keḍikeḍi tua vinaikan a łevavaw.
qao tjemomalj azoa kedrikedri toa vinaikan a ljevavaw.
S.TRANSL: And the child told them about how she had gone up above.

S.FORM: "tazua qemaung a ku sinvał; qau mayanga ku piqan.
"tazoa qemaong a ko sinvalj; qao mayanga ko piqan.
S.TRANSL: “The brother I was carrying was crying, not to mention how tired I was.

S.FORM: qau vaik aken a sema tjua mui a qatsiłay, sa ku senay.
qao vaik aken a sema tjoa moi a qaciljay, sa ko senay.
S.TRANSL: So I went to the quartz rock and sang.

S.FORM: manu mangtjez a tsemas, sa sualapi ti aḍing; sa katsu-i aken a sema vavaw itjua kalevelevan.
mano mangtjez a cemas, sa soalapi ti adring; sa kaco-i aken a sema vavaw itjoa kalevelevan.
S.TRANSL: And a god came and took the boy off me; and I was taken up to heaven.

S.FORM: łakua tutsu sinan ałak anga ken nua tsemas.
ljakoa toco sinan aljak anga ken noa cemas.
S.TRANSL: But now I have been adopted by the god.

S.FORM: ini anga muri i tjumaq aken," aya azua keḍikeḍi.
ini anga mori i tjomaq aken," aya azoa kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: I won’t be at home any more,” said the child.

S.FORM: qau patjara kełangan nua kina katua kama tu niamadju a ałak.
qao patjara keljangan noa kina katoa kama to niamadjo a aljak.
S.TRANSL: Then the mother and father realised that it was their child.

S.FORM: vetseqelen a lima a kula; masengats anga semau.
veceqelen a lima a kola; masengac anga semao.
S.TRANSL: They held onto her arms and legs; they didn’t want to let her go.

S.FORM: "mayanga vaik.
"mayanga vaik.
S.TRANSL: “Don’t go!

S.FORM: imaza-i anga," ayain nua matjałałak.
imaza-i anga," ayain noa matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: Let’s all stay here!” her parents said to her.

S.FORM: łakua ini kisalu azua keḍikeḍi.
ljakoa ini kisalo azoa kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: But the child wouldn’t agree.

S.FORM: avan a "pavayi aken tua vaqu tu tjelu a vatan," aya.
avan a "pavayi aken toa vaqo to tjelo a vatan," aya.
S.TRANSL: Instead she said: “Give me three millet seeds.”

S.FORM: qau malap a matsidił, sa pakauvuan tua quvał nimadju.
qao malap a macidilj, sa pakaovoan toa qovalj nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: She took them herself, and put them in among her hair.

S.FORM: tsuay anga pagału, "muri vaik anga ken.
coay anga pagaljo, "mori vaik anga ken.
S.TRANSL: After a while she said: “Now I’m going.

S.FORM: łakua ku katsuaw tsu a vaqu.
ljakoa ko kacoaw co a vaqo.
S.TRANSL: But I’ll take this millet.

S.FORM: nu tjału kalevelevan aken, ku sitalem anga tsu.
no tjaljo kalevelevan aken, ko sitalem anga co.
S.TRANSL: When I get to heaven, I’ll plant this.

S.FORM: qau nu liaw anga, a maisu anga tu ku kanen a matsidił, nu maisu aken, ki zemuzung.
qao no liaw anga, a maiso anga to ko kanen a macidilj, no maiso aken, ki zemozong.
S.TRANSL: When it has grown and when I pound grain for myself to eat, when I’m pounding it will thunder.

S.FORM: łakua, ku marekakama, azua a maisuisu tua ku kanen, aya-u anga."
ljakoa, ko marekakama, azoa a maisoiso toa ko kanen, aya-o anga."
S.TRANSL: But, my parents, think that it’s me pounding my food.”

S.FORM: qau paetez nua kai.
qao paetez noa kai.
S.TRANSL: That was all she said.

S.FORM: mintu maulaw; ini kełang tu sema inu.
minto maolaw; ini keljang to sema ino.
S.TRANSL: She disappeared, and they didn’t know where she had gone.

S.FORM: avan anga kama katua kina sakamaya a qemauqaung i tjumaq.
avan anga kama katoa kina sakamaya a qemaoqaong i tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: So the father and mother were just left at home crying.
